awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: A Novel P300 Brain-Computer Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Brain computer interfaces (BCIs) translate basic mental commands into computer-mediated actions, thereby allowing the user to bypass the peripheral motor system and interact with the world directly via brain activity.  These systems are being developed to aid users with motor deficits stemming from neurodegenerative disease, injury, or even environmental restrictions which make movement difficult or impossible.  One of the most successful classes of EEG-driven BCI systems is the P300, which works by detecting user responses to flashed stimuli.  In most P300 systems, a grid of letters and/or other symbols is presented and rows or columns of the symbols are flashed in random order; the user attends to the desired symbol (usually by silently counting when it flashes).  A major problem with these grid-based P300 systems is that the user must ideally look at the flashed target and minimally attend to the tiny letters, but late-stage ALS and other locked-in patients for whom these systems are most needed have trouble foveating targets and making controlled eye movements.  The PI's hypothesis is that a BCI that flashes segments of one large letter can retain the combinatorial efficiency that comes with querying several letters at once, while having the advantage of one central focus (no gaze shifts required).  This research aims to design and test this new segment speller idea.  Project outcomes have the potential to vastly improve the usability of P300 EEG-based BCI systems for those with visual, sensory and motor impairments.  All software written for EEG signal processing and analysis will be made available as add-ons to EEGLAB which is distributed by the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience (SCCN) at UCSD and part of the Temporal Dynamics of Learning Center.  Data will also be made available through the HeadIT data archive that is also run by the SCCN.

This research task can be broken down into three main objectives: develop and test the response to flashed segments; improve the single-trial classification of the responses to flashed segments; and design a logic for selecting segments and interpreting their responses.  The developed system will provide another method for BCI speller control that does not depend on the ability to shift gaze.  The PI argues that this method will have a higher information transfer rate than other space invariant BCI spellers due to being able to probe multiple letters at once.  Besides being advantageous for those with impaired eye movements and/or impaired vision, the method should have other advantages over the standard P300 systems.  When errors are made, they will tend to be to visually similar symbols. Incorporating language priors and active segment selection is easily accommodated, and this may result in higher information transfer rates with slower flash rates.  In addition the work on improving recognition of single-trial temporal EEG signals and incorporating Bayesian language models into spellers could be useful for other types of brain-computer interfaces.

por.por_cntn:
Brain computer interfaces (BCIs) were originally conceived for people who are completely locked in, unable to volitionally control their body including vocal cords and eyes, eliminating all usual forms of communication.  One common BCI speller interface involves letters and numbers laid out on a grid (see Figure 1).  Individual rows or columns are flashed somewhat randomly and users attend to their flashed target and internally count when their desired letter flashes.  This internal counting results in a small, noisy, voltage fluctuation that can be detected at the scalp. By averaging the response to several stimuli, the BCI can infer the desired "target" letter.  The problem with these systems is that users need to look near their target letter, and those completely locked in are unable to volitionally control their eyes.  An alternative is to present all letters sequentially in a central location which results in a longer time to see and "count" an adequate number of the target letter presentations.  The goal of this project was to develop another way of probing for letters centrally by dividing letters into a set of segments that can be combined in various ways to represent all the letters (see Figures 2 and 3). In this way, probing with one segment can probe all the letters for which that segment is a part.

A system to synchronize video data from arbitrary sources and frame-rates with EEG was developed.  An unplanned outcome was the discovery and fix of an error in synchronization code that many labs use for synchronizing presentation of the stimuli (the flashed stimuli) and recording of the brain data. It is critical that these stimuli be precisely synchronized to obtain the most consistent brain responses and best chance of correctly decoding the activity.  The finding resulted in a  change to the PyXDF library used by many labs to import binary files in a commonly used format.

The mathematics were developed to determine, in real time, the stimulus to flash to maximize the expected gain in information about the target letter.   In addition to the 10 segments, letters may also be flashed when the system is narrowing down its guess of the target letter (see Figure 4). Responses to letters are slightly more classifiable and this is built into the expected information computation.   The computation also takes into account that the signals are noisy and that, at fast presentation speeds (every 587 ms; see Figure 4), the neural response to the previous flashed segment (from 300-800 ms after the flash) has not been processed before the system needs to decide on the next segment to flash.  Several methods were also developed for improved classification of EEG data.

The original segment library was designed to use a small number of natural, easy to remember, segments but that resulted in some letters consisting of more segments than others (see Figure 5).  While subjects were able to code letters with these segments, it was found that the response to target segments decreases when the target letter consists of more segments (see Figure 6).    This means that either the segment to letter mapping should be redesigned so that each letter is coded by just a few segments or information about the target response size should be used in updating the inference about the target letter after each response - where larger responses give stronger evidence for letters with fewer segments, and smaller responses more evidence for letters with more segments.  Further work to determine the explanation for the decreased target response with increasing target set size may provide more insight into the underlying EEG signal which may be helpful for Cognitive Neuroscience research.

Over the period of the grant, the PI's undergraduate BCI class grew from 15 to 194 students.   Work from this project helped develop a scaffolded exercise on processing EEG from spellers that is critical for being able to scale the class to this size; there is a Python and Matlab based version and they are available for download on github.   A new outreach presentation that allowed students to see their raw EEG signals as well as use them to control a musical dancing penguin object was developed and presented to area elementary, middle, and high school students. 

The two main funded researchers on this project came from backgrounds underrepresented in science.  They both started on the project as post-bac researchers and they are both now successful PhD students at Duke and UC San Diego.  Female undergraduates mentored on the project are now graduate students at Caltech and Duke.
